Award.AwardTitle: African American Racial Identity and Coping with Racial Stressors

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Racial discrimination is a frequent and often pervasive phenomenon in the lives of many African Americans. Research reveals that more than 60 percent African American adults report encountering racial discrimination in their lives. Frequent experiences with racial discrimination appear to come with some cost to the psychological and physical well-being of African Americans. Indeed, racial discrimination has been consistently implicated in mental health and physical health outcomes for African Americans. Although most of the previous studies linking racial discrimination to measures of mental health have utilized cross-sectional data, recent longitudinal research suggests a causal link between the frequency of perceived racial discrimination and psychological distress such that experiences of racial discrimination leads to subsequent distress. There is also evidence linking racial discrimination to Cardiovascular (CV) activity and physical health outcomes among African Americans. Importantly, not all African Americans are impacted equally by discrimination. One potential source for this differential vulnerability is racial identity. Racial identity is defined as that part of the person's self-concept that is related to her/his membership within a race. The goal of this project is to determine how racial identity attitudes influence appraisal and coping with racial hassles in African American students' everyday lives, whether these students appraise and cope differently with racial and nonracial stressors, and whether racial stressors have a more negative effects on students' mood and cardiovascular activity compared to nonracial stressors. This research project uses mixed-methodologies and consists of five interrelated studies that will explicate the processes by which college students' racial identity attitudes and situational factors interact to influence how they appraise and cope with racial hassles in their everyday lives.

The broader impacts of this research are evident in that it will shed light on the physiological implications of racial discrimination that have been linked to broader racial disparities in educational achievement and attainment as well as well being and health for African Americans. The research conducted within this project will also provide an opportunity for students from underrepresented groups to gain greater exposure to psychological research as research assistants and study participants, and will provide a valuable training experience for a number of undergraduate and graduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research indicates that experiencing racial discrimination is a common occurrence for the majority of African Americans and that experiencing racial discrimination is associated with several deleterious outcomes. Researchers have begun to conceptualize racial discrimination within a stress and coping framework in order to understand how racial discrimination impacts the lives of African Americans. The present research project builds on this work by investigating how African American college students experience and cope with racial discrimination.  The project consisted of three studies.

Study 1 examined African American college students’ daily experiences with race-relevant and non-race relevant experiences with stressful events over a 30-day period. Each day participants completed an on-line survey of their stressful experiences and measures of their daily mood as well as their physical and psychological functioning. Participants answered questions about the stressor including whether or not the stressor had anything to do with race and how they coped with the events. A primary research question was whether the students experience less positive psychological functioning during days in which they experienced a racially stressful event compared to days in which they experienced a non-race related stressor and compared to days in which they did not experience any stressor. Participants reported less positive outcomes on days they reported experiencing a stressor (regardless of whether it was race or non-race related) as compared to days that they reported experiencing no stressors. Our findings were inconclusive as to whether participants experienced more positive outcomes on days that  they experienced a race stressor versus days that they experienced only a non-race stressor. With respect to coping differences, participants utilized fewer coping strategies focused on solving the problem in racially stressful events as compared to non-racially stressful events. 

Study 2 was a research experiment in which we examined the interaction between race related cues in a situation and public regard attitudes of African American college students to determine the impact of unfair treatment on the students’ mood. The experiment included three different conditions where participants experienced the same scenario in which they were unfairly denied an opportunity to win an i-pod. One condition had no cues indicating that race was the reason for the unfair treatment (no race cues condition), a second condition had a single, subtle cue implicating race as the reason for the unfair treatment (subtle race condition), and a third condition included a blatant cue implicating race for the unfair treatment (blatant race condition). Public regard attitudes (the extent to which individuals believe that other groups hold negative attitudes towards their group) were assessed prior to the start of the experiment.  In both the subtle and blatant race conditions, individuals who believe that other groups have more negative attitudes towards their group (low public regard) were more likely to attribute race as the reason for their unfair treatment.   Public regard attitudes were unrelated to attributing race as the reason for unfair treatment for individuals in the no race cue condition. Also, individuals in the subtle and blatant race conditions experienced more negative attitudes than individuals in the no race condition even though all participants were treated equally unfairly.  Finally, holding low public regard attitudes was associated with more negative mood in the subtle condition, but associated with more positive mood in the blatant condition.  Public regard attitudes were unrelated to mood in the no race cue condition.

Study 3 utilized a similar procedure as that in study 2.  In this study, the focus was on blood pressure as the primary outcome. We found significant differences in conditions for diastolic blood pressure, but no differences for systolic blood pressure. Individuals in the blatant and subtle race conditions exhibited higher diastolic blood pressure once they were unfairly treated as compared to those individuals in the no race condition.  Individuals in the blatant and subtle race conditions had similar diastolic blood pressure. Public Regard attitudes were unrelated to any of our cardiovascular measures.

The intellectual merit of the research project can be found in the creative and rigorous way in which the study was conducted.  The study also contributes to the existing research literature in its finding that across a number of different outcomes, experiencing unfair treatment as being the result of race is associated with less positive outcomes than experiencing similar unfair treatment that is not based on race. The project represents one of the few controlled experiments examining African Americans’ experiences with racial discrimination. The research project has had several broader impacts on society including addressing a major issue within our society (racial discrimination) that has resulted in numerous inequities. The research project also provided students from traditionally under-represented groups greater exposure psychological research as research assistants and study participants.  Finally, the research project provided career development opportunities for several African American graduate and undergraduate researchers.
